o
jecture, be accepted of her Hig
es

What might folowe suche a preface, yo
r

c

ch

For if I had concurred w
t

at he had formerly proposed, at his be[.]
sea, because it might have hapned,

the states, had bin secretly told it, by so[.]

o
ference, it would have wrought a [.]
cion of intelligence between us, and the[.]

In w
ch

ted to yo
r

negotiation I have spedde beyonde my hope of
favorable issue, for as farre as I have brought it
and for so short a poursuite. I may ima-
gine very safely, up
o
this their deputation,
a
d by

at it is not yet surmised,
that there passeth in secret any special correspon-

r

ch

e maneging
of o
r

t

and
in this most of all
,
at he was thus appointed,
to come and conferre, and after to report my spee-
ches to
e states: w
ch

well

will be diligent, and carefull. Howe
e

w
at

as I should ghesse

I hope to a

at

for a while to keepe his court at

bu[t]
nothing heere besydes of special considerat[ion]
most part of

S
r

[And so]
